Change mapping to just "/certificate". In REST, when we want to get list of values for some (filtered or not) we usually call just GET /.
In general bunch of static global flags look like terrible idea.
Do you actually use builder for GiftCertificate? If not, you can drop the annotation.
Do you actually use builder for Tag? If not, you can drop the annotation.

That's not a good approach. We do not want to compare strings to check result. Please, make TagValidator return Optional (empty optional would mean Valid) or better custom class ValidationResult with boolean "valid" field and String "message" field. Than since this method is used only in save, just inline entire logic of it into saveTag method. Thus you avoid additional null comparison there.
I would highly advice wrapping tag into Optional, when returning from giftCertificateTagRepository (and unwrapping here). But is up to you.

You do second request to DB for same tag here. Back on line 34, where "tagExists =..." instead save result as Tag. Calculate tagExists on the next line as "tagExists = tagFound !=null". Thus, you would only do getTagByName once.
Why request it again, if you return entire Tag from "saveTag" method? Could not you use "tag" instead of "tagResponse"?
Make it return Optional<String>
Optional.empty()
Optional.of(String.join...)
Same here with the Optional
You pass in GiftCertificate, but your controller expects GiftCertificateRequestDTO

This is problematic operation. You do NOT copy "giftCertificate" into  "giftCertificateResponse1". You instead point second name to the same object. Now, both "giftCertificateResponse1" and "giftCertificate" are same and changes to one, would apply to other. Which is problematic, since "giftCertificateResponse1" supposed to have more fields set later. Please, replace this line with
giftCertificateResponse1  = new GiftCertificate(
"certificate for test", "description for test", 10.50, 10L);
to create separate independent copy.

I have thought about improving this part. My suggestion: is doing it like this example: https://chat.openai.com/share/86b29c8a-ba4c-479c-9dfa-e102bc9c92a8

node.title: Use an immutable workspace for all non-incremental transforms
node.body:
Previously project-bound transforms were always executed in a mutable, project-bound workspace, even when they were non-incremental. By allocating immutable workspaces for non-incremental work we get to reuse their outputs locally more often without having to hit the build cache.

A consequence of this change is that running `clean` does not remove the outputs of non-incremental project-bound transforms anymore. Only the outputs of incremental transforms will be stored in `$buildDir/.transforms`.

Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/26694

nodes.bodyText:
Also, what do you think about this suggestion: #26792 (comment)?

I think it's important to have "identity" mentioned in that name. We can remove "identity" once we can drop the non-normalized version.
I've triggered a build for you. Click here to see all failures if there's any.
Pre-tested commit build failed. Click here to see all build failures.
I've triggered a build for you. Click here to see all failures if there's any.

node.bodyText: In general, I am good with the approach to use Gradle user home workspaces for non-incremental project transforms, as long as their input artifact are normalized. There still will be some negative effect for folks that don't use @Classpath on their input artifacts when those are project artifacts. Also, it seems like some test coverage is missing - given that we now have three options how to decide on a workspace, we'd need to have one extra variation of quite some tests, right?
🤔 This also means that we'd use the in-memory cache for non-incremental project transforms. Is that a problem?

🤔 I am surprised you can calculate the unique id up front now, given that we had the different subclasses with specialized identities before so we'd avoid calculating them when doing the locking on the loading cache. Are you sure this doesn't introduce any performance regressions?
❌ We still want a test here that a non-incremental project transform execution can be up-to-date or from the build-cache, right?
❌ We'd be losing some test coverage here by not checking what happens for non-incremental project transforms.
❓ Are we losing some coverage here?
❓ Again, are we losing some coverage here?
❓ Do we now need some test coverage for non-incrementally transformed artifact directories as well?
❔ I don't understand why we don't need this optimization any more when we move to all-scheduled transforms. Though it is also not very important in this context.
❓ Would we need a test here that this works as well for incremental transforms?
🤔 Maybe we can skip "Identity" from the name and have only NonNormalizedImmutableTransformExecution
Or maybe even UnnormalizedImmutableTransformExecution

🎉So we use normalized for projects, nice.
I guess here performance regression are not seen, since project normally doesn't have a lot of project dependencies, right?
❔ Do we still need that now, that we don't include it in equals?
Yeah, I was also somewhat surprised. But ran the performance tests and they show no regression, see link above.
We need this because it gets accessed from IdentifyTransformExecutionProgressDetails.
Why would it be a problem? Because of the additional memory usage?

My understanding is that this optimization is needed because we "execute" transforms every time their output is needed, and then we de-duplicate the many executions in the IdentityCache step. For external artifacts like guava.jar we run the identify part for every subproject where the transformed JAR is needed; for large projects the difference between using the snapshot vs using the fingerprint can add up.
Once we change this and all transforms are discovered as part of execution graph building my expectation is that we can do this de-duplication based on the identity of the transformed dependency instead. This is just an assumption, though, that I haven't verified, so I'm okay with removing the comment here.

I'm not sure I understand your question about performance. We already used normalized for project artifacts (both incremental and non-incremental). And why would the number of dependencies matter for calculating a hash for the primary artifact?

I understand that we could do the de-duplication while scheduling, though that also means we'd do the identification there. In other words for de-duplication we need to identify a transform, and if my understanding is correct that doesn't change whether we schedule the transforms or not.

In this spike #26765 we did normalization for all artifacts, so we did see some performance regression. But quoted sentence explains my question why we don't see regression here:

We already used normalized for project artifacts (both incremental and non-incremental)



And why would the number of dependencies matter for calculating a hash for the primary artifact?

I should phrase it differently: my assumption was that in dependency graph there is less project dependencies than external dependencies, and that is why we don't see any regression. But my assumption was incorrect and we don't see any regression because we anyway did a normalization already before as mentioned above.
Adding a test for that.
This is the same comment essentially as the one a few lines higher, correct?
Added a test specifically for non-incremental transforms.
Added a where: clause.
I don't think we need that here. This is not about testing how the transform is executed, but about the fact that you can use the output of an included build as an input to (some) transform.
Yep, that's correct.

As discussed in person: my expectation is that we can de-duplicate while creating the execution graph by observing the input artifact's coordinates, and that'll be somehow cheaper. Or we can use the input snapshot there if that doesn't work. But here we will be able to use the full fingerprint instead.
I've removed the comment in any case.
Added coverage for both incremental and non-incremental.

LGTM overall, added some comments if we could 💅 some tests.
Also, what do you think about this suggestion: #26792 (comment)?
💅This looks a bit complicated, can it be simplified with a table?
💅 Would it make sense to split this test in two?
💅 What if we set this in the where: table instead of having imperative logic here?

While I agree this is not the nicest API from Spock, we do use .combinations() in several other places in our tests to handle similar situations where we need to test all the combinations of two vectors. This format lets us discuss the two dimensions without introducing redundancy.
I tried doing the de-normalized table version, but I'm not sure I like it any better:
where:
incremental | sensitivity
true        | null
true        | PathSensitivity.ABSOLUTE
true        | PathSensitivity.RELATIVE
true        | PathSensitivity.NAME_ONLY
false       | null
false       | PathSensitivity.ABSOLUTE
false       | PathSensitivity.RELATIVE
false       | PathSensitivity.NAME_ONLY
I don't feel strongly either way, so let's go with your suggestion.

Like into two test cases? I think that would make things worse. Incrementality should have little to do with what this test is about, we are only checking both cases to be extra sure. For that reason I think it's better to have the if here. To be honest, I think it would also be okay to remove this last when:/then: section.
Once again I don't feel strongly either way, so I made the change.

I talked to the Chat about this, here's the gist of what it said, and I mostly agree:



"Non-normalized" is more neutral and simply states the absence of normalization without implying that normalization should have occurred. It suggests that the data has not been subjected to the process of normalization, and it's more of a passive state. It's commonly used in technical and scientific contexts where precision is valued.


"Unnormalized" could suggest that the data was normalized at some point and has been changed back to its original state, or it could also just indicate the lack of normalization. However, in practice, "unnormalized" is often used in mathematics and computing to simply mean "not normalized," without necessarily implying a process of denormalization.


Given that "normalized" data implies that an active process of normalization has been applied, using "non-normalized" would unambiguously indicate that this process has not been applied, and there is no suggestion that it is a state that has been reverted to. Thus, "non-normalized" might be the more technically appropriate term for your case, emphasizing that this is the default or natural state.

https://chat.openai.com/share/2901f5fc-81a4-4c6c-a3d3-604e19e1b90f
Yes.
I am not sure if it makes a difference whether the transform is incremental or not for the reuse. I'd be happier if there were a test for this.

We already used normalized for project artifacts (both incremental and non-incremental).

I don't understand this. For project artifacts, we used a mutable workspace, so we didn't normalize the contents for the workspace location. And now instead, we put non-incremental project transforms into a normalized immutable workspace location. We did normalize the inputs of project transforms in every build, since they have not been a part of the cross-build identity cache.
I think the main point here is that we didn't change anything for external dependencies regarding their workspaces, so this extra work doesn't show up.

❓ There are quite a few tests that use multiProjectWithJarSizeTransform() and, by extension, registerFileSizer that now all use non-incremental transforms. I think most of those tests should be added for incremental transforms, especially transform is applied to each file once per build, transform is run again and old output is removed after it failed in previous build,  and maybe a few more.
